Incident.Summary: Impaired driver arrested on traffic stop

AddressCommonName.CommonPlaceName: WB LIBERTY RD / 0-0 WORMANS MILL RD

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Unmarked Car B11: Footage recorded and uploaded.
Body Worn Camera: Footage recorded and uploaded.
Assisting Troopers/Officers: Frederick City Police, Walsleben #176F

Attachments:
Citation 3DJ0V4
Marroquin Soma DR15
Marroquin Soma DR15A
METERS Printouts
SFST Field Notes

Defendant: Lesly Yanira Marroquin Soma
Date of Birth: 10/20/1990
Date of Arrest: 1/28/2023 at 0116 hours
Subsequent Offender: Yes
CDL: No

Narrative:
On January 28, 2023 at approximately 0051 hours I was on duty, in uniform, operating unmarked car B11 on patrol in Frederick County, Maryland.

Vehicle In Motion:
I observed a white Honda CR-V MD 4DM4935 traveling on US 15 northbound, occupying both the travel lanes by straddling the dotted center line. The Honda merged to the exit lanes to MD 26 eastbound, where it failed to drive in a single lane. As it approached the traffic signal to Worman’s Mill Rd, I observed the Honda swerve out of its lane almost completely into the adjacent lane, and then suddenly swerve back into its lane. It came to a stop at the red signal light, and when it turned green, proceeded through. I then activated my vehicle’s emergency equipment to initiate a traffic stop. The Honda slowed almost to a stop in the travel lane for several seconds, then abruptly accelerated forward. It continued through the intersection with Monocacy Blvd, continuing to swerve out of its lane. The vehicle swerved into the bicycle lane to the right at Sebastian Blvd, narrowly missing a curb. Approximately 3 minutes and thirty seconds after I activated my emergency equipment, the Honda came to a stop in the turn lane to Latham Drive.

Pre-arrest screening:
I made contact with the driver and identified her by her Maryland driver’s license as Lesly Yanira Marroquin Soma (MD M625511947810). Marroquin Soma was seated in the drivers’ seat of the vehicle, with the vehicle’s keys in the ignition and the engine running. Immediately upon making contact with Marroquin Soma, I detected the strong odor of alcoholic beverage on her breath and person. I requested her driver’s license and registration, and she searched the interior of the vehicle for an extended period of time before I reminded her that I needed her driver’s license. She produced her driver’s license, and I asked for the nature of her travel. She advised that she was going home to Walkersville, immediately after verifying that her residence was Logan Street in Frederick. I inquired how much alcohol she had, and she asked, “Hmm?” Looked at her passenger, and then asked, “Me?” She squinted, shook her head, and asked, “What do you mean?” Then she asked, “Why are you asking that?” I advised her that I was asking because of her poor driving and the odor of alcoholic beverage, she replied that she would not answer how many alcoholic drinks she had consumed.

Due to my observations of her driving and the odor of alcoholic beverage,  I requested that Marroquin Soma exit the vehicle and conduct Standardized Field Sobriety Tests, to which she agreed. She advised that she had no medical issues, took no medications, and had no injuries or eye conditions.
 
I am trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. I have additional training in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement and the Maryland Highway Safety Office Impaired Driving Conference.

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Test: refused.
I explained the test to Marroquin Soma, advising her to watch the tip of my pen, and follow it with her eyes only, without moving her head. Marroquin Soma advised that she understood the instructions and did not have any questions. I held the stimulus approximately twelve (12) to fifteen (15) inches from her nose, just above eye level, and conducted the test. Marroquin Soma displayed equal pupil size and equal tracking in both eyes.

I attempted to conduct the test approximately 4 times, repeating the instructions each time. Marroquin Soma followed the stimulus with her head, stared past me and not at the stimulus, and snapped her gaze from straight forward to the stimulus’ location without tracking it. It was my opinion that Marroquin Soma was attempting to defeat the test.
 
Walk and Turn Test: 3 of 8 clues observed (2 or more clues indicate a 79% likelihood of BAC at or above .08).
I explained and demonstrated the test to Marroquin Soma. I advised her to stand on an imaginary straight line with her right foot in front of her left, her right heel touching the toes of her left foot. I instructed her to keep her arms down at her sides and to remain in that position until instructed to begin. I instructed her to take nine heel-to-toe steps, turn without lifting her front foot off the ground, by taking a series of small steps and take nine heel-to-toe steps back. I instructed her to count her steps out loud, keep her eyes on her feet, keep her hands at her side, and not stop walking until she completed the test. The test was performed on the concrete sidewalk beside the roadway where her vehicle was stopped, which was level, dry, and smooth. Marroquin Soma opted to take her shoes off, as they had high heels.

During the first series of steps, Marroquin Soma stepped off line on the first step, crossing over her legs and exclaiming as he stumbled. She stopped and looked at me and I prompted her to continue. On step 4 she missed heel to toe contact by more than one inch distance. On the second series of steps, Marroquin Soma missed heel to toe contact by more than one inch on steps 4, 6, and 7.  

One Leg Stand Test: 2 of 4 clues observed. (2 or more clues indicate an 83% likelihood of BAC at or above .08).
I explained and demonstrated the test to Marroquin Soma. I advised her to keep her hands at her side, pick a foot to raise, lift that foot six (6) inches off the ground, keep her eyes on that foot, and count out loud by thousands. I instructed her to keep the foot raised until I ended the test.  Upon completion of my explanation and demonstration, Marroquin Soma asked several times how long she was to lift her foot. Each time I advised her it was until I ended the test. She made several statements about needing to “go to the gym” in order to complete the test. Marroquin Soma raised her left foot and immediately put it down several times. She never counted out loud, so I started the timer on the third time she lifted her foot. She held her foot raised, swaying the entire time. She put her foot down again at 12 seconds. She did not pick her foot up again until I ended the test.
Based on my training, knowledge, and experience in the Maryland State Police, I determined there to be probable cause that Marroquin Soma was driving while impaired. I offered her a Preliminary Breath Test, which she agreed to take. I instructed her to seal her mouth around the straw and forcefully blow her breath through it, but she sucked air in through the straw several times. When she did finally blow out through the straw, she did so extremely weakly. In spite of the poor sample, the result of the PBT was 0.08 BrAC.
I placed Marroquin Soma under arrest at approximately 0116 hours. Her vehicle was towed from the scene since it was stopped in a travel lane. I read Marroquin Soma her DR-15 Advice of Rights and at approximately 0130 hours I marked her response as a refusal as she would not answer. I transported Marroquin Soma to the Frederick Barrack, issued her a DR15A, the attached citations, and confiscated her license. I released her to Garcia-Reyes, Alexandra Nicole (G626044630856), who had a valid license and no warrants.
All events occurred in Frederick County, Maryland.
Case closed.
